title: Problem Overview
content: This header documents **Erdős Problem #236** about counting representations n = p + 2^k. Let f(n) count such representations where p is prime and k ≥ 0. The question: Is f(n) = o(log n)?
mathContext: f(n) := |{k : n - 2^k is prime}|. Erdős (1950) proved infinitely many n have f(n) ≫ log log n. The conjecture asks if f(n)/log n → 0.

title: The Counting Function f(n)
content: **f(n)** counts solutions to n = p + 2^k where p is prime. We iterate k from 0 to log₂(n) and count those where n - 2^k is prime.
mathContext: def f (n : ℕ) := |{k ∈ [0, log₂ n] : Prime(n - 2^k)}|. This is computable via filtering and checking primality.

title: Trivial Upper Bound
content: **Proved**: f(n) ≤ log₂(n) + 1 always. Since we only check k ∈ {0,...,log₂(n)}, we can have at most log₂(n) + 1 valid representations.
mathContext: f_trivial_upper_bound : f n ≤ Nat.log2 n + 1. The proof uses that filtering a list cannot exceed its original length.

title: Concrete Values
content: **Proved/Axiomatized**: f(2)=0, f(3)=1, f(5)=1, f(9)=2, f(15)=3. Small cases verified by decide or explicit computation.

title: All-Prime Property
content: **HasAllPrimeProperty n** means n - 2^k is prime for ALL k with 1 < 2^k < n. These numbers are extremely rare.
mathContext: HasAllPrimeProperty n := ∀ k, 1 < 2^k → 2^k < n → Prime(n - 2^k). Conjectured to be exactly 7 such numbers.

title: Small All-Prime Numbers
content: **Proved**: 4 and 7 have the all-prime property. For 4: only 4-2=2 (prime). For 7: 7-2=5, 7-4=3 (both prime).
mathContext: four_all_prime : HasAllPrimeProperty 4; seven_all_prime : HasAllPrimeProperty 7. Proved by case analysis on k.

title: Erdős-Guy Conjecture
content: **Conjecture**: The only all-prime numbers are {4, 7, 15, 21, 45, 75, 105}. Verified up to 2^44 by Mientka-Weitzenkamp (1969).

title: Main Conjecture
content: **Erdős Problem #236**: Is f(n) = o(log n)? Formally: the ratio f(n)/log(n) tends to 0 as n → ∞.
mathContext: Erdos236_Conjecture := (fun n => f n) =o[atTop] (fun n => Real.log n). Uses Mathlib's asymptotic notation.

title: Erdős Lower Bound
content: **Erdős (1950)**: f(n) ≫ log log n infinitely often. There are infinitely many n where f(n) ≥ c·log log n for some c > 0.
mathContext: axiom erdos_lower_bound : ∀ C, ∀ᶠ n in atTop, ∃ m ≥ n, f m ≥ C * log log m. Shows the conjecture, if true, is tight.

title: Vaughan's Sparsity Bound
content: **Vaughan (1973)**: All-prime numbers are extremely sparse. Their count up to N is at most N·exp(-c·(log log log N / log log N)·log N).
mathContext: This is a super-polynomial decay rate, much faster than any polynomial. Shows all-prime numbers are astronomically rare.

title: Connection to Problem #10
content: Problem #236 counts representations n = p + 2^k, while Problem #10 asks if every odd n has such a representation. f(n) = 0 means no representation exists.
mathContext: HasRepresentation n := f n > 0. Numbers with f(n) = 0 cannot be written as p + 2^k. Example: f(262) = 0.
